si9.svg svg 8680 ALTIMG YJCAT 115823 115823 S0021-9517(24)00536-0 10.1016/j.jcat.2024.115823 The Author(s) Fig. 1 Redox wave taken from a CV scan in the potential range of 1.0 V − 1.9 V (vs RHE) after CV conditioning done in a potential range 1.0 V − 1.5 V (vs RHE) a) with no conditioning, b) 200 CV, and c) 1200 CV, d, e, f) Cathodic charge density for the samples in a, b, and c, respectively. Fig. 2 In-situ Raman of the NiOOH decay in OCP. a) Raman signal of the sample cycled 1200 times. Every scan corresponds to a 2.1-minute recorded spectrum. b) Linear decay of the NiOOH phase measured in OCP from the sample cycled 1200 times as obtained by integrating the NiOOH Raman signal. c) Raman signal of the sample cycled 200 times. The Raman signal has a low S/N ratio due to the low NiOOH amount. d) Self-discharge of the sample conditioned under 1200 CVs. Although the NiOOH decay is linear according to the Raman signal, the OCP sequentially shows a presumably exponential, linear, and polynomial region. e) self-discharge of the sample conditioned under 200 CVs. It shows a faster NiOOH decay and f) self-discharge of the sample that was not conditioned by CV. g) In-situ UV–Vis Reflectance Spectroscopy decay in OCP of a sample cycled 1200 times. The minimum reflectance scan corresponded to the sample when it was polarized at 1.5 V (vs RHE), and the later consecutive scans corresponded to changes in reflected light during the self-discharge. h) Reflectance change was taken at 650 nm and plotted vs the potential scan of the decay. i) Full self-discharge of the sample conditioned 1200 CV with a NiO thickness of 15 nm as used for the reflectance measurements. Fig. 3 Time dependence of potential in open circuit self-discharge of region 1 (1.50 V − 1.32 V). a) The system is plotted to determine if the potential decay is through ohmic leakage. The absence of a linear fitting corroborates that ohmic current does not impact this region. b) the time dependence of potential in open circuit self-discharge is plotted to find Faradaic contributions. Again, the absence of a linear region shows that the Faradaic reactions do not govern the self-discharge in this region. Fig. 4 Time dependence of potential in OCP discharge is plotted to determine if ion diffusion contributes to this potential region. The linear fitting shows the predominance of diffusion-limited contributions in this potential region (1.50 V − 1.32 V (vs RHE)). Fig. 5 Time dependence of potential in OCP. a, b, and c second region (1.32 V − 1.25 V). d, e, and f third region (1.25 V − 1.0 V). a), d) the system is plotted to determine if the leakage current is through ohmic resistance. b), e) the time dependence of potential in open circuit self-discharge is plotted to find Faradaic contributions. c), f) the system is plotted as V vs. t1/2 to verify diffusion contributions. Fig. 6 A) full ocp for the sample that was cycled 200 times. it can be seen that the ocp consists of more than 3 regions. b) third, fourth, and fifth potential regions plotted as a function of ln t to verify charge redistribution processes. the linear fall shows this process predominates the self-discharge after 1.25 V (vs RHE). Graphical abstract NiOOH has been established as the active phase of NiO-based electrocatalysts in the alkaline Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER). Here, we investigate the self-discharge behavior of NiOOH electrodes under open circuit potential (OCP) conditions in 1 M KOH electrolyte by monitoring phase changes via in-situ Raman and UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopies and performing kinetic analyses on the OCP and spectroscopic data. Our findings reveal a linear phase change from NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 over time, indicative of a 0th-order reduction reaction. Contrarily, the OCP evolution associated with this phase reduction displayed a combination of linear and exponential decay patterns as a result of various kinetics, including Faradaic processes and diffusion-controlled mechanisms, influencing the self-discharge potential over 1.25 V (vs RHE). An additional linear region at lower potentials (<1.25 V (vs RHE)) suggests that charge redistribution due to the phase change from α-Ni(OH)2 to β-Ni(OH)2 dominates the self-discharge, a behavior confirmed by in-situ UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining in-situ Raman and UV–Vis spectroscopy with electrochemical data for real-time monitoring of electrochemical processes, here potential-dependent electrocatalyst phase changes, leading to a more detailed and accurate understanding of the dynamic behavior, phase change kinetics, and self-discharge behaviors of solid electrocatalysts that can guide the design of more efficient and durable energy storage and conversion materials. Keywords Oxygen Evolution Reaction NiOOH Raman Spectroscopy UV–Vis Reflectance Spectroscopy Phase Transition OH− ion diffusion Self-Discharge Data availability Research data supporting figures and tables in main text and supplementary information is made available via ZENODO.org under https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13903343. 1 Introduction Nickel-based oxides are extensively used in secondary batteries, supercapacitors, and as electrocatalysts for the alkaline OER.[1–5] Consequently, comprehending the role of the different NiO-derived phases, captured in the Bode diagram [6] as a function of applied potential and reaction conditions is crucial for advancing efficient and cost-effective renewable energy storage and conversion technologies. However, investigating some of these phases, like NiOOH or α-Ni(OH)2, using ex-situ or in-situ techniques presents challenges due to the instability of these phases outside operating potentials, both decaying to the more stable β-Ni(OH)2 phase. [7–10] Several papers have used Raman spectroscopy to identify and study the NiOOH active phase in OER [10–13] due to its convenience over other techniques, such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) or transmission electron microscopy (TEM), that do not allow for phase transition measurements under operating conditions or techniques that allow phase transition but typically require synchrotron measurements such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) or X-ray diffraction (XRD). In a previous paper, [10] in-situ Raman spectroscopy was used to study the decay of the NiOOH under open circuit potential (OCP) conditions—the investigation aimed to gain insights into the decomposition mechanisms of NiOOH. It was shown that, when removing potential control, i.e., setting OCP conditions, NiOOH shows a spontaneous voltage drop, which was attributed to the instability of this phase outside specific applied potentials under alkaline media and under atmospheric conditions. Other authors have shown the thermodynamic instability of the oxy-hydroxide phase as well. [14,15] However, no kinetic analysis of this decay has been addressed so far, and a detailed understanding of the self-discharge process is still missing. The combination of pseudocapacitance and double-layer capacitance in nickel-based electrodes can influence the overall energy storage and charge-discharge characteristics. This combination leads to a more intricate electrochemical situation where electrostatic and redox mechanisms contribute to charge storage. Supposing the system is simplified to an electrochemical capacitor, the primary mechanism behind energy storage is charging and discharging the electrochemical double layer (EDL). [16] Then, the energy is stored in the electrical potential across the double layer. The EDL is the closest region to the electrode surface, containing ions from the electrolyte solution attracted to the charged electrode. [17] It follows the diffuse layer with space charge [18] that contains a distribution of ions with varying concentrations, gradually adapting bulk electrolyte properties and potential. However, nickel oxide and hydroxide demonstrate a pseudocapacitive behavior. The pseudocapacitance for these metal oxides is voltage-dependent, typically exhibiting a direct correlation between the stored charge and the applied charging potential. The main source of this charge storage arises predominantly from electron-transfer mechanisms through redox reactions, as opposed to the electrostatic accumulation of ions in the electrochemical double layer; [19–22] and when the capacitor is disconnected from the external circuit and placed in OCP conditions, the stored charge dissipates. Several factors that have been listed in the literature [23–26] can simultaneously account for the charge dissipation process of the electrochemical capacitor, where one of the main factors is the leakage current. Every practical EDL capacitor exhibits a degree of leakage current (ohmic leakage) that travels through resistive routes within the electrolyte and electrodes, gradually discharging the stored charge. This phenomenon is attributed to structural or mechanic defects such as porosities in the electrode material. [26] The ohmic leakage in an electrochemical capacitor is governed by the solution resistance Rs and the double-layer capacitance Cdl. The RsCdl-time constant affects the capacitor's discharge behavior. [23,25,27–29] Eq. (1) shows the voltage of a discharging capacitor through a resistor, which yields a linear profile when plotting ln V vs t. (1) l n V = - t R s C d l where V , Rs, and Cdl correspond to the electrode's initial potential, solution resistance, and double-layer capacitance, respectively. In case faradaic charge transfer dominates the reaction kinetics of the system, the Butler-Volmer equation (eq. (2) describes the relation of the current passing through the electrode and the potential difference of the redox reaction. [24,25,30] (2) i = i 0 e α F η R T - e - α F η R T where i is the current density in mA cm−2 at an overpotential η , and i 0 is the exchange current density, α determines the slope between η and log i in the Tafel relationship. As NiOOH reduces under OCP, we consider only the second term related to cathodic reactions. The faradaic process should lead to a linear dependency of the capacitor voltage on ln t for a semi-infinite medium, [25,28] according to (3) V = R T α F l n α F i 0 R T C - R T α F ln t + C i 0 where C is capacitance. Other models also propose a self-discharge by a diffusion-controlled mechanism, resistance-limited charge redistribution, or a self-discharge due to a mixed Faradaic reaction and charge redistribution. [29,31–33] The observed self-discharge in electrochemical capacitors and similar energy storage devices is well-established, as it is essential to identify and understand the self-discharge process, minimize it, and optimize the production of electrochemical storage materials. [25,29,34] However, the intricate chemical and physical processes responsible for self-discharge exhibit complexity, rendering their identification challenging. It necessitates a comprehensive understanding of the identity and reactivity of all materials within the electrochemical capacitor and a deep understanding of charge migration within the materials. This study employed specular external in-situ UV–Vis reflectance and in-situ Raman spectroscopies on NiO/Ni electrodes prepared via DC magnetron sputtering under OCP conditions. We conditioned the electrodes with different cyclic voltammograms in 1 M KOH to produce varying amounts of Ni(OH)2, which helps stabilize different amounts of the NiOOH phase. Using specular external UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy, we tracked the optical response of the phase change under in-situ conditions as a function of potential and time. This response is well-known because of the electrochromic phenomenon associated with nickel oxides and hydroxides. The material changes its optical properties in response to an applied electric potential, where it reversibly alters its appearance between transparent (bleached state) and dark (colored state) upon charge insertion and extraction. [35–38] In reflectance, the intensity of the reflected light is affected by absorption and changes in the refractive index at the interface, as reflection occurs at the boundary between different phases. [39] Our system (electrode–electrolyte–electrochemical cell) is assumed to be a multi-phase medium comprising air, a quartz window, liquid electrolyte, varying thin film catalysts, and a substrate of infinite thickness (polished Ni disc), where the deposited catalyst layer behaves as a multilayer thin film system of varying thicknesses in response to the applied potential. When the film is in contact with KOH, different phases such as α, and β-Ni(OH)2, and β, and γ-NiOOH will form simultaneously, depending on the applied potential. This multilayer system creates multiple interfaces where light reflects, absorbs, or both. Therefore, it is not straightforward with UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy to distinguish a specific interface's individual complex refractive index from the absolute collected reflectance spectrum. Some authors have calculated the corresponding complex refractive indices for these multilayer systems. [40–42]. We correlate changes in the UV/vis reflectance and the Raman spectra to the self-discharge kinetics in OCP, presenting insights into the mechanisms happening during the self-discharge of a system reducing from Ni3+ to Ni2+. The self-discharge potential associated with the NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 phase change exhibited distinct trends during the process, and the corresponding kinetic analysis shows that diffusion processes, Faradaic reactions, and charge redistribution dynamically influence and determine the observed self-discharge voltage drop. To form the NiOOH phase, we polarized the electrode at 1.5 V (vs RHE) for 10 min. The transient cell current of this polarization can be described by eq. For short times (t < 0.1 s), the capacitive current contributes considerably to the total cell current [34] according to eq. (5). (5) i c a p t = V R u e - t R u C d where V is the absolute value of the applied voltage across the capacitor, Ru is the uncompensated resistance, Cd is the double-layer capacitance, and t is the time. The Cottrell equation for diffusion limiting current is given by (6) i d i f f = n F A C 0 D π t where n is the number of electrons involved in the reaction, F is Faraday's constant, A is the active electrode area, C0 is the initial ionic concentration, and D is the ion diffusion coefficient. It is clear that in real operational applications, electrolyzer systems commonly are operated under continuous conditions. While this is distinct from OCP, the phase change behavior we observed in this study provides a foundational understanding of the material's redox stability and potential-dependent transformations, which are relevant. The knowledge gained under OCP conditions helps us predict how the material might behave in real-world applications, especially during rest or low activity periods. This is especially relevant when considering different load scenarios of alkaline water electrolyzers when operated with fluctuating renewable energy, i.e., solar or wind energy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample Preparation Ni discs of 12 mm diameter were polished using 15 µm and 8 µm silicon carbide (Starcke, Struers) and 0.5 µm alumina paste (MicroPolish Alumina, Buehler). NiO thin films of 10 and 15 nm were prepared by DC magnetron sputtering using a Ni target (Kurt J. Lesker with purity 99.99 %). Two mass flow controllers (MKS) were used to introduce 0.2 sccm of O2 and 19.8 sccm of Ar (Air Liquide with purity 99.995 % and 99.999 %, respectively). The working pressure was set to 3 × 10−2 mbar, and the plasma power to 15 W, with a substrate to target distance of 20 cm. 2.2 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra were acquired with a LabRAM Horiba HR-800 Raman microscope with a 633 nm laser. The power density at the sample was 1.9 mW at a spot size of 1.5 μm using a 50 × long working distance objective. A 600 grooves per mm grating was chosen, the diameter of the pinhole was set to 200 μm, and the entrance slit size to 200 μm. Per spectrum, 13 scans of 10 s acquisition time were accumulated every 2.1 min. An Asymmetric Least Squares (ALS) background subtraction was applied in the specified regions of interest to facilitate the plotting and interpretation of the spectra. 2.3 In-situ UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy The in-situ UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy setup is depicted in Fig. S1. An AvaSpec-ULS409CL-RS-EVO spectrometer with a range of 190 nm to 1100 nm was used to detect the corresponding change in reflectance. A Deuterium-Halogen lamp (AVALIGHT-DHC, Avantes) with a range of 200 nm to 2500 nm was used as a light source. AvaSoft software recorded the reflectance spectra changes, which were then processed and analyzed using Origin Lab. Each reflectance spectrum was smoothed using the adjacent-averaging method for 50 adjacent data points. A sample with 15 nm of NiO was prepared on a mirror-like polished Ni disc for these experiments. The sample was exposed to 1200 CVs from 1.0 V – 1.5 V (vs RHE) with a scan rate of 100 mV/s to form a thicker hydrous Ni(OH)2. When the system stayed in OCP conditions, consecutive UV/vis scans were recorded every 2 min for 12 h. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were conducted in a three-electrode setup in a PECC-2 cell from Zahner Elektrik, controlled by a potentiostat from Gamry instruments (Interface 1000E). All measurements were performed in 1 M KOH (Carl Roth, unpurified, Fe < 7 ppb by ICP-OES). Before the measurement, a Hg/HgO reference electrode from ProSense was calibrated against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) (HydroFlex, Gaskatel). The counter electrode was a platinum wire. By an electrochemical impedance measurement at OCP, the current response during cyclic voltammetry (CV) was manually iR–corrected in the data post-treatment. The conditioning consisted of repetitive voltammetry cycles in the 1.0 V − 1.5 V (vs RHE) range with a scan rate of 100 mV/s. Three samples were exposed individually to 0, 200, and 1200 CVs to form different amounts of hydrous Ni(OH)2. Additionally, 3 CVs before and after the conditioning were measured between 1.0 V − 1.9 V (vs RHE) with a scan rate of 50-mV s1 to verify the redox wave behavior. The same system was used to perform the UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy measurements. Electrochemical measurements for in-situ Raman were performed using a TSC Raman cell from rhd instruments. It was operated in a three-electrode configuration. A gold-plated ring was utilized as the counter electrode at the base, while a leak-free micro Ag/AgCl electrode from Innovative Instruments served as the reference electrode calibrated against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE, HydroFlex, Gaskatel). Potential control was executed using a Gamry Instruments potentiostat (Interface 1000E). The NiOOH phase was formed in the film by polarizing it using chronoamperometric measurements at 1.5 V(vsRHE) for 10 min (corresponding to a potential above the Ni2+/Ni3+ oxidation wave). 2.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Studying the sample by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) before and after CV conditioning helped to determine if the sample underwent a phase transformation from NiO to Ni(OH)2. After conditioning, the samples were extracted from the electrochemical cell, holding a potential of 1.0 V (vs RHE), rinsed with Millipore water, blown dry with nitrogen, and immediately transferred into an ultra-high vacuum (UHV). XP spectra were acquired using a SPECS PHOIBOS 150 spectrometer implemented at the DAISY-FUN cluster tool. It is equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (monochromatic Focus 500 with XR50 M (SPECS), hv = 1486.74 eV). Survey and detail spectra were measured in fixed analyzer transmission mode while choosing a pass energy of 20 eV (step size of 0.5 eV) for the survey and 10 eV (step size of 0.05 eV) for the core levels. The system was calibrated to 0.00 eV binding energy of the Fermi level of sputter-cleaned Au and Cu as well as to the emission lines of Au 4f7/2 at 83.98 eV, Ag 3d5/2 at 368.26 eV, and Cu 2p3/2 at 932.67 eV binding energy with deviations ≤ 0.1 eV. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Cyclic voltammetry Cyclic voltammetry was conducted over the potential range of 1.0 to 1.5 V (vs RHE) at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1 to induce the formation of varying amounts of the Ni(OH)2 phase. The redox waves from the obtained voltammograms are shown in Fig. 1 . These are similar to those reported in the literature corresponding to Ni oxides and hydroxides. [10,43] The cyclic voltammogram shapes show that the potential sweep leads to a quasi-reversible electron transfer [44] of the Ni2+/Ni3+ redox reaction. The oxidation peak between ∼ 1.32 and ∼ 1.46 V corresponds to Ni(OH)2 oxidation to NiOOH. Fig. 1 shows that the redox peak amplitudes increase with more CV conditioning. A higher amplitude is related to an increased formation of hydrous Ni(OH)2, [45,46] ensuring a faster oxidation process to NiOOH due to intercalated water molecules in the crystal structure. The formation of the hydrous Ni(OH)2 phase increases the electrochemically active surface area, facilitating the ionic diffusion to previously inaccessible metal centers. [47]. From the redox waves, we can retrieve the anodic and cathodic charge density by integrating the current density as q t = ∫ V 1 V 2 i ( t ) d t , with V1 and V2 being the potential limits for the reduction and corresponding oxidation waves. We show the cathodic charge density in Fig. 1d-f. The charge density increased from 0.69 mC cm−2 for a non-conditioned sample to 2.34 mC cm−2 for a sample cycled 1200 times. We correlate the charge increase to the total amount of Ni(OH)2 within the film if one electron per nickel atom is assumed in the redox process. Therefore, a 240 % increase in Ni(OH)2 is calculated for the increased charge density. The value can be estimated from N = Q e , where e is the elementary charge, Q is the charge in coulombs, and N is the number of electrons, assuming a percentage increase = [(2.34 – 0.69) / 0.69] * 100 %. 3.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. S2 displays the Ni2p and O1s core levels captured through XPS of two samples after conditioning with 200 and 1200 CVs. The analysis of the O1s core level reveals the presence of Ni(OH)2 at 531.3 eV and a discernible signal of NiO remaining at 529.2 eV visible for the sample cycled 200 times. The primary peak in the Ni2p spectrum at 856.0 eV is characteristic of Ni(OH)2, as indicated by previous studies [10,48–51]. It should not be confused with NiOOH phase, as this phase is not expected to appear in these spectra due to its thermodynamic instability outside applied potentials, especially when the substrate is exposed to water (during the rinsing) and atmospheric conditions. [10]. 3.3 In-situ Raman spectroscopy In-situ Raman spectroscopy was used to study the Ni3+ to Ni2+ transition in real time. After the different CV conditioning, the samples were placed in the Raman cell and polarized for 10 min at 1.5 V (vs RHE). This polarization process induces the formation of NiOOH. In Fig. S3, we illustrate the different phases forming behind this approach. The formation of large amounts of NiOOH phase was crucial for efficient Raman detection. As we were not using surface-enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS), a sufficiently thick NiOOH phase was required to obtain usable S/N ratios for the analysis of the Raman data. Fig. 2 a,b,c show the time-resolved in-situ Raman spectra recorded for the samples cycled 1200 and 200 times in OCP conditions after 10 min of polarization at 1.50 V (vs RHE). In the sample cycled 200 times, only a low amount of NiOOH phase was formed; therefore, recording its Raman signal resulted in a low S/N ratio. No NiOOH Raman signal was recorded from the sample that was not conditioned. As soon as the system enters self-discharge, the NiOOH phase relaxes, as shown in Fig. 2a and 2c. For the samples cycled 1200 and 200 times, the phase decay recorded with Raman takes approximately 120 and 50 min, respectively, showing that the NiOOH lifetime depends on the amount of NiOOH phase formed, which in turn depends on the initial amount of Ni(OH)2 formed by the different CVs cycles. The corresponding analysis of this Raman signal can be found in a previous publication. [10] However, unlike the previous report, the samples presented here have no NiO or Ni(OH)2 contributions to the Raman signal. Integrating the Raman signal shows a linear NiOOH decay with time, meaning a 0th-order reaction (Ni3+/Ni2+) within the potential region 1.50 V − 1.26 V (vs RHE). 3.4 In-situ UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy In addition to Raman, we used UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy to study the Ni3+ to Ni2+ phase change by tracking coloration changes in real-time. After conditioning a sample containing 10 nm NiO with 1200 CVs, it was left in KOH for 12 h to reach a constant OCP of 0.7 V (vs RHE) and a completely bleached state. After this, before the 1.5 V (vs RHE) potential is applied, a background was taken and subtracted from the initial reflectance spectrum; therefore, the reflected light is at its maximum intensity (100 %) from 380 to 900 nm, as seen in Fig. S4. Next, the sample is polarized at 1.5 V (vs RHE) for 10 min, after which it stays in OCP for more than 12 h. Fig. 2g shows the corresponding reflectance spectra for the sample polarized with the subsequent OCP. The reflected light intensity decreases due to the formation of NiOOH (colored state), and once the system enters the OCP, the reflected light intensity is enhanced for more than 720 min, meaning that the film coloration associated with the formation of NiOOH diminishes as the phase decay to a β-Ni(OH)2 (bleached state), a full description of the spectra, the coloration mechanisms, as well as the approach, is explained in our previous publication. [52] Similar to the Raman signal, a linear increase in the reflected light (0th-order reaction for the Ni3+/Ni2+) is observed in the potential region 1.5 V − ∼ 1.26 V (vs RHE). However, unlike Raman, it is possible to observe a change in the reflected light intensity at lower potentials due to the higher sensitivity of the coloration change. This additional signal comes after an inflection point, giving rise to another linear decay with a lower slope, indicating smaller changes in the optical response. One might think that the change in reflected light intensity under 1.26 V (vs RHE) could still suggest the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+. However, these slower changes in reflected light intensity are more likely related to the aging of α-Ni(OH)2 to β-Ni(OH)2 in the alkaline electrolyte. These two hydroxide phases have different refractive indices: α-Ni(OH)2 = 1.41–0.0i and β-Ni(OH)2 = 1.46–0.0i, as measured by Visscher et al. [53] Therefore, as we have shown before, [52] the small linear increase in reflected light intensity at potentials below 1.25 V (vs RHE), when only Ni(OH)2 is present, could be due to differences in the real part of the refractive index rather than changes in an absorption band provided by the NiOOH phase. Thus, small changes in reflected light at low potentials are not associated with NiOOH reducing to Ni(OH)2. 3.5 Discharge mechanisms in OCP conditions After 10 min polarization at 1.5 V (vs RHE), the system is let to relax in OCP. At this point, the electrochemical capacitor discharges. Fig. 2 d-f, i shows the self-discharge voltage drop observed for the sample that was conditioned 1200 and 200 times and with no conditioning. Initially, the discharge profile was divided into three distinct regions, each displaying different characteristics. An apparent exponential decay is visible in the first region, followed by a linear decay and a possible polynomial decay in the last region. An exponential decay pattern is observed in the discharge mechanism of electrochemical capacitors, primarily due to self-discharge mechanisms such as ohmic leakage and the characteristics of the electrochemical double-layer capacitance. These factors contribute to gradual discharge over time, particularly noticeable when the capacitor is not actively charged. [25] Conversely, a linear decay can occur due to factors such as gradual depletion of reactants or changes in electrolyte composition. In the case of the described electrochemical system, faradaic charge transfer reactions, prompted by local overcharging and charge redistribution resulting from NiOOH instability, may contribute to sustained changes leading to observable linear decay in the second region. As we mentioned before, it is evident from the time frames discharge of these samples that the potential decay lifetime depends on the amount of NiOOH phase produced during the 10-minute polarization at 1.5 V (vs RHE). The amount of NiOOH phase formed depends on the amount of the Ni(OH)2 phase produced during the different conditioning cycles. The more Ni(OH)2, the more NiOOH and, consequently, the slower the self-discharge decay. When fitting the potential decay, an exponential function with two-time constants in superposition to a linear and a polynomial function is required to fit the multiple regions, making the system very complex for only having a self-discharge by ohmic leakage and faradaic process. Hence, we will also consider a diffusion-controlled process and charge redistribution to complete the reaction kinetics. Let us analyze the regions of the sample cycled 1200 times step by step. First OCP Region (1.50 V − 1.32 V) . When the first region of the self-discharge potential from Fig. 2d is plotted as ln V vs t (Fig. 3 a) according to eq. (1) it does not follow the typical linear behavior expected for a self-discharge mechanism of an electrical double-layer capacitor (EDL) modeled by Conway. [25,31] Consequently, the self-discharge in this region cannot be solely ascribed to the ohmic leakage of a typical electrochemical capacitor. [24,28] Hence, other processes, such as faradaic or diffusion mechanisms, could contribute to the self-discharge in this region. An inspection of V vs ln t, according to eq. (3) (Fig. 3b) does not show a predominant linear behavior for the region, indicating that the voltage decay does not follow a fully Faradaic self-discharge either. Hence, a diffusion-controlled process is introduced as a rate-limiting step for the self-discharge in the region between 1.5 V and 1.32 V (vs RHE). After charging, a concentration gradient of ions forms across the electrolyte, with higher ion concentrations near the electrodes. During self-discharge, the potential decreases as the chemical potential energy stored in the oxidation state Ni2 + to Ni3 + dissipates. Ions will naturally diffuse from regions of high concentration to regions of low concentration, leading to a redistribution of ions. This diffusion process can cause a slow loss of potential across the electrodes. Slower ion transport affects the ion distribution within the diffuse layer of the electrical double layer (EDL), causing the system to discharge more slowly. Additionally, ion diffusion within the solid phase can further increase internal resistance, resulting in voltage losses during discharge and ultimately reducing the device's efficiency. In an ideal case, where the system is purely diffusion-limited, the current is given by (7) i d i f f = - A D d C d z where d C d z , A , D are the ion concentration gradient perpendicular to the surface, the electrode surface area, and the diffusion coefficient, respectively. From eq. (7), a potential variation in time can be obtained according to (8) - C dl d V d t = A D d C d z Eq. (8) shows how the ion concentration varies in space and time, where Cdl is the capacitance. Its solution can be found by solving Fick's equation (9) ∂ C ∂ t = D ∇ 2 C where ∂ C ∂ t gives the concentration change with time, D is the diffusion coefficient, and ∇ 2 C is the Laplacian of concentration that represents the spatial variation of concentration. For simplicity in the solution, we consider a planar disc of radius r, where we assume that the only diffusion happening is in direction z perpendicular to the surface; therefore, no radial or lateral variation of the concentration is assumed. In this way, for a semi-infinite system, the problem is simplified to a one-dimensional diffusion problem, and the concentration variation is given by [27] (10) C z , t = C 0 + ( C s - C 0 ) e r f z 2 D t where C0 is the initial concentration of the diffusion electroactive species, Cs is the concentration at the electrode surface at (z,t = 0), D is the diffusion coefficient, and erf is the error function. Therefore, the current entering the electrode surface at time t due to the diffusion of species is given by (11) i d i f f = - A D d dz C 0 + C s - C 0 erf z 2 D t From the previous equation, the plot of V vs t 1 / 2 should result in a straight line if the diffusion-limited process dominates the self-discharge. [25,29] Fig. 4 shows that the self-discharge potential in region one is diffusion-limited to a larger extent. It should be remembered that for analytical solution simplifications, eq. (11) is based on a semi-infinite diffusion within the electrolyte, [25,28] where no influence of electric fields on the diffusion rate is considered. Second (1.32 V − 1.25 V) and Third (1.25 V − 1.0 V) OCP Region Using the same assumptions, Eqs (1), 3, and 11 can also be applied to the second region of the OCP decay. This region ranges from ∼ 1.32 V − ∼1.25 V (vs RHE) according to the linear sections in the OCP decays (Fig. 2 d-f). From Fig. 5 b, it is clear that Faradaic reactions happening at these potential ranges control the reaction kinetics. Let us remember that this potential region coincides perfectly with the reduction wave in the cyclic voltammogram, as seen in Fig. 1. After 1.25 V (vs RHE), an inflection point exists, making the potential change rate steeper. After this inflection point, we examine the third region (Fig. 5 d-f), but for this sample, using the mathematical relations established above, we cannot disentangle the self-discharge mechanism. Therefore, to have a complete view of the self-discharge potential at this region, the sample that was cycled 200 times was left in OCP until the potential stabilized in a steady state condition. Fig. 6 shows that more than 3 regions could be assigned, where the inflection point ranges from ∼ 1.25 V to ∼ 1.22 V. A fourth linear region ranging from ∼ 1.22 V to ∼ 1.04 V, and an apparent exponential fifth region at last. This linear decay (1.22 – 0.98 V (vs RHE)) correlates with the optical changes observed in the UV–Vis reflectance spectra (Fig. 2 g-i), suggesting a transition from α-Ni(OH)2 to β-Ni(OH)2. We hypothesized the occurrence of this transition, considering the differences in the refractive index of these two hydroxides, also due to the aging of the α-Ni(OH)2 to a more stable β-Ni(OH)2 phase where the intercalated water molecules leave the film. Additional analyses beyond this study's scope, like thermogravimetric or Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) could help verify our hypothesis. However, Yi et al., [54] have shown that absorbed or intercalated water in β-Ni(OH)2 is much lower than in α-Ni(OH)2 or αβ-Ni(OH)2 phase, giving rise to a very distinct FTIR and Raman spectra. This phase change affects the electrochemical double layer as dehydration alters the system's local chemical environment and electrochemical potential. Therefore, this linear self-discharge may arise as charge redistribution occurs in the system, leading to a steady decrease in potential. In this region, the slope of this new linear region cannot be the negative of the Tafel slope of a Faradaic self-discharge reaction given by eq. (3), since no Faradaic processes (Ni3+ to Ni2+) are expected to occur at such low potentials. Several authors have modeled this linear discharge for non-Faradaic self-discharge processes for porous electrochemical capacitors as a linear fitting in the V vs ln t. [55,56] Fig. 6b shows that the self-discharge profile falls linearly with ln t in the potential region ∼ 1.22 V to ∼ 1.04 V. An important consideration in analyzing the self-discharge of the electrode under OCP conditions is to consider the state of the electrode right before entering the OCP, as this can affect the capacity and rate of self-discharge. The supplementary information (Fig S5) presents these additional considerations by analyzing the chronoamperometric measurements from which an OH– ion concentration profile is simulated at different applied potentials (Fig S6). The concentration profile model, designed to visualize the ion distribution at the electrode surface right before the open circuit potential (OCP) starts, indicates that once the oxidation begins (when the oxidation potential is applied), the OH– concentration at the electrode surface becomes lower than in the bulk solution. Consequently, the OH– concentration at the electrode surface is dependent on the electrode potential. Therefore, a higher applied potential results in a lower OH– concentration at the electrode surface. 4 Conclusions The use of OCP in this study was crucial for observing the phase change from NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 over time without external perturbations, allowing us to capture the natural evolution of the material's oxidation states and phase composition. While OCP conditions differ from traditional cyclic voltammetry and real-world operation, this approach provides important insights into the kinetically driven processes that occur after the material has been activated. In cyclic voltammetry or real operational conditions, phase transitions like the formation of NiOOH and its subsequent reduction to Ni(OH)2 can occur under dynamic potential conditions. However, these two different processes (CV and OCP) are still governed by the same underlying thermodynamics, and the material experiences similar redox transitions. The key difference is that during cycling, these transitions happen more quickly and are influenced by the applied potential and current flow, whereas at OCP, we capture the slower, natural relaxation of the system as it reaches equilibrium. The reduction of NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 under OCP conditions in 1 M KOH demonstrates a 0th-order reduction reaction characterized by a linear decay over time, as evidenced by in-situ Raman and UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopies. However, the self-discharge potential involving the phase change from NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 indicates a more complex behavior, incorporating both Faradaic reactions and diffusion-controlled processes, resulting in a combination of exponential and linear decay patterns. During extended OCP decay, an additional linear self-discharge section emerges after an inflection point at 1.25 V (vs RHE), followed by a plateau at approximately 0.7 V (vs RHE). As confirmed by in-situ UV–Vis spectroscopy, this behavior suggests that charge redistribution due to the phase change from α-Ni(OH)2. to β-Ni(OH)2 is the dominant self-discharge mechanism at lower potentials. These findings underscore the effectiveness of combining in-situ Raman and UV–Vis spectroscopy for real-time monitoring of electrochemical processes. This approach provides a more detailed and accurate understanding of phase change dynamics and self-discharge behaviors, which can guide the design of more efficient and durable energy storage and conversion materials. coredata.dc:description: NiOOH has been established as the active phase of NiO-based electrocatalysts in the alkaline Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER). Here, we investigate the self-discharge behavior of NiOOH electrodes under open circuit potential (OCP) conditions in 1 M KOH electrolyte by monitoring phase changes via in-situ Raman and UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopies and performing kinetic analyses on the OCP and spectroscopic data. Our findings reveal a linear phase change from NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 over time, indicative of a 0th-order reduction reaction. Contrarily, the OCP evolution associated with this phase reduction displayed a combination of linear and exponential decay patterns as a result of various kinetics, including Faradaic processes and diffusion-controlled mechanisms, influencing the self-discharge potential over 1.25 V (vs RHE). An additional linear region at lower potentials (<1.25 V (vs RHE)) suggests that charge redistribution due to the phase change from α-Ni(OH)2 to β-Ni(OH)2 dominates the self-discharge, a behavior confirmed by in-situ UV–Vis reflectance spectroscopy. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining in-situ Raman and UV–Vis spectroscopy with electrochemical data for real-time monitoring of electrochemical processes, here potential-dependent electrocatalyst phase changes, leading to a more detailed and accurate understanding of the dynamic behavior, phase change kinetics, and self-discharge behaviors of solid electrocatalysts that can guide the design of more efficient and durable energy storage and conversion materials.
